The opening of the book introduces readers to Lieutenant Jefson on the day he is shot down while flying over the Argonne Forest in February 1915. As he recovers in a German hospital, he reflects on his past opposition to war, having once been a member of a Peace Society. This internal conflict sets the stage for Jefson's transformation from a peace advocate to a soldier, compelled to defend civilization against aggression. The narrative explores his thoughts on the folly of pursuing peace at the expense of national preparedness, ultimately leading him to embrace his role in the war. This introspective beginning hints at a deeper commentary on the moral ambiguities of conflict and the journey of a character navigating the complexities of loyalty, duty, and personal ideology amid the chaos of war.
